An elegant and simple restaurant with wonderful udon. I came here with a group of four at 4:30 and was seated right away. Service was quick and efficient. I got the sansai udon and enjoyed it very much. The noodles were delicious, white, and chewy; the broth was authentic; and the mountain vegetables were exactly what I had been looking for. The restaurant exuded clean and simple Japanese aesthetic, completing the charm of my meal. Highly recommend, and I hope to be back next time I'm in NYC.

The noodles were perfect thickness and firmness. The broth was very interesting unlike any noodles I've had before, a bit on the salty side but I thoroughly enjoyed the experience. The place is small so waitlist is long, but we got in without waiting too long, probably because people dropped out.
No comment

When the first time I got the best popular one(beef something) , honestly I was disappointed. The udon soup was salty and little sticky so personally not good.. however some menu like gatsu-dong and mushroom udon were really awesome! If you have low threshold of a salty taste, I would recommend you to get a mushroom udon.

Oh my gosh. What a Beautiful work, beautiful food. I don't think I've had better Udon in my life. We ordered 3 different kind of Udon and I couldn't believe all of them had different dashi. I don't think I can ever go back to Tsurutontan after visiting here. I was so so so impressed. One amazing thing is their of rice. A simple bowl of rice was so shiny, moist, fluffy and tasty. Amazing Japanese pride. Thank you. Beyond delicious.

We ordered Niku udon, Jia Jia don, chicken tatsuta, ankimo, spent $60 in total. We highly recommend the chicken tatsuta, the meat is really tender. Ankimo is the fish liver, I myself like the taste of liver, so I would recommend Ankimo also.

I've had Raku twice so far. This place makes me wonder, what Udon have I been eating my entire life. I had the Niku Udon on both of my visits. It was superb and delicious. The noodle is served with large beef chunks and honeycomb tripe. The broth is amazing. Portion size is huge! The bowl is so big you can probably take a bath in it. Note that it's cash only, and it doesn't take any reservations. Don't forget to get the Chicken Tatsutaage for appetizers. You won't regret. This is by far my favorite Udon place in the City.
I wish I could eat their Kitsune udon everyday. The noodles were so good & broth was delicious. Chewy noodles all day!

This place is pretty good. I usually go to ramen restaurants, but my friend brought me here last time and I was in love. I didn't know there are Udon restaurants around. Recommend for people to try out this place!

Words can't accurately express how much I liked this place. I've never had udon that was so perfectly cooked. I got the duck and scallion and the broth was so rich in flavor. Unfortunately, I thought the duck was pretty tough but the broth and amazing noodles made up for it. My husband got the niku (beef short rib and honeycomb tripe) which was also delicious. I really don't think you could go wrong with anything on the menu here and I can't wait to come back!
Good portion if you're hungry and craving for carb. Will recommend you order this if you are there at first time;)
Outstanding service, great food, unique restaurant. Alcohol options were good, I had a hot sake and really enjoyed it. A must if you are in the area.

Several great appetizers, especially the thick cut bacon. Relatively good noodles with flavorful broths. Frozen grapes at the end a nice touch. Cramped and uncomfortable seating. Overall a good experience and I would go again to test it a second time, but was not blown away

What a hidden gem on the lower east side!! Very authentic Japanese cuisine. Could tell owners were Japanese. A very simple menu, but there is at least an order or two for everyone. Wait staff is very friendly! Space is tight, but then again most good restaurants in Manhattan are fairly small. Been here 2 times, and don't know when it would be my last ;) definitely check it out, but don't spoil the low profile vibes of the restaurant!

A very cozy restaurant with incredibly generous portion sizes (I've never seen such a big bowl used for udon before). Had the chicken tatsuta-age ($7) and the chicken curry udon ($14). Chicken tatsuta-age was nice but a bit fatty on some parts, though it came with a nice dipping sauce. The udon had a good texture mild kick of spice to it but overall wasn't too memorable/unique in terms of taste; perhaps this is the simplicity many yelpers here seem to otherwise enjoy. I left full but also wondered if I should have ordered another udon instead.

Raku serves up some awesome Udon varieties. The bowls are huge and portions are consequently filling. The honeycomb tripe definitely makes the niku udon a winner, while the curry udon is also quite delicious. The appetizers are great too -- the karaage is crispy without bones, the monkfish liver has a nice sauce to it. Service, however, was insanely slow. We had to waive to the staff to get anything moving. Also, for comfort, pray that you'll not be placed at the side bars.

Raku in East village has a very cozy homey vibe. Tables are closer together and more of an intimate environment. My guests and I were seated immediately and our food came just on time! Nothing complain and it's one of the best Udon places in east village!

Great ambiance and fast service. Marinated fried chicken app was amazing and the udon is elevated, with amazing noodles and broth. Still think about it from time to time. Definitely worth the wait!

No comment

This is by far the best udon place I've had in New York. This is not your typical udon spot- I believe the udon is homemade. The noodles are so soft and chewy. When I came I had the short rib and honey comb udon and my friend had the kani one. My broth was very flavorful and the meat was so tender. My only complaint is that the broth got a little too salty for me towards the end. My friends crabmeat udon was filled with chunks of crabmeat. The service was really good. Just a note, the restaurant is very small and hidden so it's really easy to miss. I would definitely recommend this place if you're going with one or two friend. Don't come with large parties!

Have been waiting to try this restaurant for a long time since I first heard all the great reviews. Even with all the hype, everything was ABSOLUTELY AMAZING. We had an assortment of appetizers and they all exceeded our expectations. Their dishes are very authentic and reminiscent of my recent trip to Japan. The udon noodles though were DEFINITELY the highlight. We had the Niku and the Gyunan and they were both super tasty. The noodles they use are unique and just the right amount of chewiness. Their broth is complex and savoury. Can't wait to come back again.

The soups are amazing! the best one was the beef and tripe (Niku Udon). The broth was super flavorful and enough to order extra noodles to enjoy with it. The udon noodles taste homemade and add a great taste to the soups. The fried chicken appetizer was also good with not a lot of fat - the dip was slightly spicy for me but seemed like it was only a spicy mayo combination. The atmosphere is tight but cute. I would say that the only two downfalls are that the soup comes out unbearably hot and takes a long time to cool down, that I left with a seared mouth that took a day to recoup. Also, it is super expensive for udon noodle soup and small Japanese dishes that it is not a place I will come to often, so it wont replace my udon go to on st.marks. FYI - CASH ONLY!
No comment
No comment

What an awesome restaurant! Only in New York City can you get udon this amazing until midnight! I went at around 10:30pm. The restaurant is really small, so if you go during prime dinner time, I bet you may have to wait. I got the fried chicken to start, some sapporo draft beer and the mushroom udon. Everything was so delicious. The noodles are some of the best noodles I've ever had, and the soup had the perfect udon broth. Not too salty. Udon places are rare, unlike ramen places. This place did it right. This is the first good (REALLY good) udon I've had in America!!

I don't even like udon but this place is something else. I got their most popular dish. It was the beef ribs with tripe. Must get. Service was good, restaurants kinda small so make sure you go their early or else you'll end up waiting.

It's a tiny room, cash only, you'll have to wait... but not as long as at Ippudo. Everything was delicious: burdock root, gyoza, udon, chicken karaage. Everyone dining inside was too cool for school, young, edgy, urban and Japanese. They must be on to something, these kids.
No comment

Finally got to try Raku last night for dinner. Raku is from the same people that opened Kura nearby. I tried the Niku udon- and it was on point. The broth was perfect for a cold winter night paired with soft braised short ribs and honeycomb tripe. I'm not a fan of tripe but this one had perfect texture and was very enjoyable. We started with the thick cut bacon as an appetizer- fatty but tasty. Prepare to wait at least 35 mins for dinner time.

My second time coming here. First time I ordered the duck one ($18). That was only okay for me...kind of bland. Today I ordered the Niku (tripe and short ribs) for 17 bucks. A lot more flavorful. I also ordered the shrimp tempura which was very crunchy and fresh. The udon here is good, but still missing a wow factor for me. The outside of the restaurant is strange. There's like no name and just a wooden door so it seems like a hidden hole in the wall spot.

Got the Niku Udon during lunch today and it was really good. The tripe is shaped like a honeycomb and tastes much better than regular tripe I usually get in other restaurants. The beef was also tender and soft. The noodles were the best part, it's not hard like other udon places I've tried. Service was also great. Definitely recommend. The place is sort of hidden and small on the inside, cash only!!
No comment

Got the niku udon, with rib meat and tripe. Â Loved all the contents of the soup, though I found the soup itself a little too sweet for my taste. Â Overall, a cool vibe for a place with virtually no sign but the cloth covering the door.
No comment

This spot is quite hidden as it does not have a sign. It's very small and crowded. The Saba sushi- hand pressed smoked mackerel sushi was good. It had a nice smokey taste and it was 3 pieces for $5. I also ordered the agedashi tofu- lightly fried and submerged in light semi sweet dashi sauce with bonito flakes. I like this dish very much. The shrimp tempura udon came with two shrimp and a tiny piece of eggplant. Portions were tiny and the pieces were very little. Tempura was nice and crispy and tasted good. The soup was rather bland. I ordered the chikura udon which had chicken - dark meat and diced and mochi. The soup was flavorful and the udon was bouncy and chewy. The mochi taste very odd and I did not like it. It felt out of place with the soup and udon. I would not order this. Overall the Udon taste good besides the mochi but portions are too small.

Love the agedashi tofu and curry udon :) make sure to add your name to the yelp waitlist before you arrive to avoid waiting too long if you plan on going during a busy time

Best udon I've ever ate! Â You can tell its homemade and cut per order. Â I got the popular Niku Udon. Â The fish broth is rich in flavor, udon is silk like tofu, and the tripe & beef were light where you can bite through every bite. Â I'd come back.
Love the noodle and soup. It is great to have something warm and light when you are catching a cold. They provide takeout service as well. The place is small but very popular.

Omg. Been to very good noodle places in Taiwan, Japan, etc, but this place tops the list. The broth is so clear yet savory. The beef is so tender. The chicken is also so juicy. And the mochi in the chicken one is sooooo good. Omg. Came in at 10pm and waited for 20min for a table.

Living in East Village, I'm just grateful that Raku exists. Eating out in New York isn't cheap, but Raku perfectly marries the good food with an affordable price. The udon noodle itself is perfection, and the broth is absolutely delicious. My go-to are usually the Kitsune and the Ankake (I'm a sucker for the classics) and if you feel like splurging a little more, I'd recommend the chicken tatsuta-age, and the agadeshi tofu. Do remember this restaurant is cash only, so if you want to save the ATM fee, bring some cash with you.

Fantastic combination of east village appeal (ie hidden gem feel) and exquisitely fresh, extremely understated Japanese noodles. For vegetarians, there are really only cold soup options (which didn't take the prize for taste). The other soups come in gorgeous pottery bowls, are huge servings and the noodles are as fresh as noodles get. They are cash only but have the cutest tiny ATM in the restaurant.
No comment
Waited over an hour past the expected time. Very limited and flavorless options for vegetarians/vegans. Seated facing a blank wall in a tight corner and the draft kept us chilly throughout the meal.
No comment

This place is just amazing. We have had many good udon before but their udon is one of the best. Their handmade udon noodle is cooked to perfection and tastefully chewy. We got few apps to start and they were all great. I got Niku udon and it was so delicious that I wanted to get the broth to go lol. My boyfriend had Chikara udon and that was also amazing. What a gem in the east village! Best udon in da city!! I'll come back when I visit NYC again next time.
No comment

The service was great and the udon was really good. The overall experience was nice and I would definitely comeback. For its price, it is definitely worth it. However, the broth and dipping sauce is a little salty but other than that definitely worth the time and money.

This used to be my favorite spot for udon because it was quite and and a peaceful environment to unwind from a long work day. Â Regardless of the change in customers the atmosphere of the place changed. the noise for a small establishment is now unbearable. They play their music at a volume that makes my ears ring. The customers shout over the speakers and it's not the same a small store front that I was used too and frequented often for. A huge part of eating out is the atmosphere and this place currently matches one of a cafeteria

The udon noodles are amazing! I usually love consuming all the broth when I order noodle soup but the duck soup I order became increasingly salty as I was eating it. My friend ordered the crab option and the soup was nice and thick like an egg drop soup. Overall I would still come back to try another dish because I really enjoyed the texture and flavor of the udon noodles.
No comment

Not bad, space is limited, seating is small but the food was traditional and not bad. Â The udon was delicious. Tempura was just right. Monkfish liver was delicious and service is well balanced. Â I will definitely be back.

I came here after recommendation at Kura. When I was dining for the second time they completely screwed up my spot on the list and told me I opted out to get text updates about waiting. I showed them the system is wrong and I didn't send any message about opting out. I had to wait extra 30 min on a Wednesday evening just because their screwed up system. Also the person who was handling the system yelled at my face and said "you should be thankful I'm even giving you guys a spot". I came here because of a personal recommendation from a chef not to get treated by garbage which ruined my night. Please look into this and get back to me. Thanks

Really great meal. The food was tasty and not too heavy. Noodles we're hand made and chewy. Agedashi tofu uses a firmer tofu than other places but still good. Pressed mackerel rolls were perfectly salty.
Amazing udon and their broth are so good! What I love the most is the texture of their udon. You could tell their udon are homemade with a secret recipe. Absolutely my favorite udon spot
No comment
Amazing udon and katsu don. Â The the egg and pork in the katsu don was perfectly cooked. Â The dashi soup complimented the katsu.

Hearty & Tasty. Definitely would recommend to anyone that thinks they don't like udon. I completely different experience. Before coming to Raku, I would never go out of my way to order udon. Now, I would come back just to have this same dish (and others!!). Definitely a big portion if you tend to eat lighter. Noodles were bouncy and the gyoza was delicious.

Nice vibe inside wth limited seating. Food was ok. The udon noodles were good but the broth was not as tasty as I expected. Dumplings were very good however. I did not like the fact that it's cash only.

I love the udon serving here. I ordered a cold broth udon with yam and an quail egg. The udon absorbed the flavor of the cold broth and the texture of it tasted just right. The yam is fresh and ground evenly.

Best Udon in town!! I will give the Niku udon 5 stars because it is simply delicious. Very small restaurant and almost missed it as well. Seating really limited but went at around 5:30 and it was not crowded. If you are down to splurge $18 on a bowl of deliciousness, I highly recommend!!!
Love the niku udon here! very tender short rib and honeycomb stripe~ not the typical round shaped udon you used to see in other place. very chewy and good taste. h

Pro tip- you can get on the waitlist via yelp if you're within a mile of Raku! Also, it's cash only!! On a Friday night waited about 50 mins for a table- Raku is an intimate restaurant featuring ~30 seats so I'd expect this is a normal wait time on weekends. They have a wide variety of both cold and hot udon dishes. I ordered the ankaki udon + added pork and a poached egg- I also enjoyed a glass of plum wine. I paid about $40 for my meal and was pleased. Only reason I'd give a 4 star vs. 5 is due to wait time and price point. I felt a little rushed when I was there but overall service was excellent. Would totally recommend this place and looking forward to coming back.
No comment

Nothing beats a bowl of freshly made, tender but also a bit chewy udon in delicious broth accompanied by marinated fried chicken on a rainy & cold day in new york. Get there early and do not take any detours even if you think you have ample time to spare - we left for the place at 10ish on a Sunday morning thinking we were super early, made a stop at Kmart, got there some 25mins past their open time and were given 25 minutes to wait, practically standing on our toes amongst six tables of slurpers in the tiny room that is Raku. If you like large chunks of beef with flanks, go for the renowned Niku udon, but be warned of the saltier broth. Know that whatever noodle bowl you get, there won't be a shortage of content, so go light on the additional orders.

Raku is a quaint little place for udon noodle. If you don't know where the place is, you might just walk by it. The decor is very basic. I had a udon noodle with tripe and short rib and my friend had a vegetable tempura udon. My udon dish was not very exciting, several pieces of beef and tripe in a broth. It was definitely not worth the amount of money i paid for it. The vegetable tempura udon was worst I felt in the amount of vegetable they gave. It was just some shredded green pepper, onion and something else. It was definitely not worth it. I also had the bacon, it was disappointing. It was more like smoked ham than bacon. The whole thing costed me about $50 after tips. I don't understand the ratings everyone gave them. I guess people were being more generous than giving them an accurate rating.
is a cozy nook on the LES, with some brilliant udon dishes, especially the Niku (which feels like Raku's signature dish). Their fried chicken is very nice as well. Raku is worth its high wait times.
They have the best udon in NYC! Service is perfect, and the bacon appetizer is a must try!
One of the best noodle places I've been to in the city. This is a very small restaurant and is cash only. But the food is amazing!

Oh my gosh, this udon is on point. It's hand made noodles, do I need to say more. The Niku broth was absolutely delicious. Also had the fried chicken and age tofu. Both were super yummy. I'd def would go back, expect a line tho cause it's a small space.

I really liked the aesthetics of this place! The service was great as well. I quite enjoyed my food, but the udon was different. It wasn't completely round and it was doughier rather than that sort of snappy chew that you expect. I didn't dislike it, but I came for udon and got something that seemed different. My soup was still very tasty, and I enjoyed the experience, but perhaps go elsewhere if you're seeking really fat, chewy udon.
No comment
So so good. When the food makes your soul feel better, you know it's good. The broth really settles the body on a chilly day!
No comment

No comment

Having gone to Japan two months ago, I've really been craving some good Udon. After scouring the internet looking and hoping for another euphoric bowl of Udon - I'm glad to have come across Raku. What makes or breaks a good bowl of noodles is the texture, in my opinion. Raku's Udon was slimy and not as chewy as I wanted, but it was still pretty dang good. My friend got the shrimp tempura udon - after claiming he wouldn't order anything since he was "full" - but upon walking in, he knew that he couldn't pass up this opportunity for some authentic Japanese Udon. I got the simple egg udon which was exactly what I wanted. The broth was a little saltier than I'd like and a little too simple for my taste, but the egg and the vegetables made it worth it. Also, it was a little chilly outside and nothing makes you feel better than a hot bowl of noodle soup on a chilly New York day. Pretty easy to find, we got there right at 11:30 on a Saturday and snagged the last table of 2. Other people after us got seats at the bar and the wait quickly became 30-40 minutes after we seated (we were super lucky!). Come hungry, leave satisfied. Good Udon, but still on the search for one that mimics Shin Udon in Shinjuku ;'( Message me any recommendations!
The noodles were ok. I prefer my udon noodles thick and soft. Their noodles tasted thinner and Â al'dente. Their dashi soup is very nice. I had chicken mochi udon. Chicken was very tender.
No comment

I enjoyed a nice, warm dinner on a cold night with a good friend. Â The fried pork dumplings were a great way to start the meal. Â I have to admit; I didn't love my duck udon. Â But I don't think I didn't love it because it wasn't good, I just don't think I'm a big udon fan. Â I prefer ramen.

Came here with my two friends. The place seems to be hidden. We walked right past it. There's no giant sign that say Raku. Instead, there's a small menu right outside. It is a small, cozy, and authentic looking Japanese place. The decor was nice. I ordered the curry beef udon. It was delicious. It was very flavorful with a mild spice to it. The broth was thick at first but once I started eating up all the noodles, the broth was much thinner. I usually like my soup broth to be thinner so I can slurp it. I would definitely come back and try the other udon noodles!

This place is solid! Their udon noodles are freshly made and chewy, definitely one of the best udon noodles I've ever had. I ordered their niku udon which is a beef broth based udon with beef briskets and honeycomb tripes, YUM YUM!!!

Cozy place reminiscent of what one could expect to find in Japan. Â I had the Oyako Don and Gyoza. Both were delicious. Service is friendly. Â My wife had Sansai Udon - comes with a huge mountain of veg tempura. She loved it as well. Must visit again.
No comment

I recommend this place if you're in the mood for a good bowl of udon. It's super small and quaint. The outside entrance is really cute and kind of takes you away. I got the niku udon which is pretty meaty but doesn't feel heavy.
No comment

Raku continues to be an unassuming and unpretentious jewel in NYC's noodle scene. A small, intimate space, Raku's simplicity works well and produces a serene environment. To me, the cold noodles are the real treat, but arrive early to get Japanese potato salad which quickly sells out. In all honesty, it's probably also the best hot noodles in NYC. Cash only, they have a cute ATM in a cabinet.

Best udon in the city! The noodles have the perfect bite to them. I'm all about the Niku Udon! The beef and honeycomb tripe! Can't wait to go back! Huge portions as well!

The best udon spot in the city!! Came here with my boyfriend around 12pm and we waited for 10 minutes for seats. The interior is very simplistic and has a very cozy feel to it. We ordered the small chicken tatsuta-age - it was very delicious with the spicy mayo sauce. I got the Niku hot udon (short rib and tripe) - everything about it was perfect. The broth was very rich and delicious and the beef was very tender. There was a good amount of beef and tripe which I was very happy about. Definitely would recommend coming here!!

Simple and good food. Excellent place if you are looking for good Udon and some small plates to nosh on with the delicious chewy noodles. My favorite so far is the seaweed udon and the plain udon with dipping sauce. The chicken udon had a good broth but the mochi was not exactly what I expected. The shrimp tempura udon was good but the broth needed a little extra kick to it which was easily fixed with the spicy sesame seasoning that they had on the table. Looking forward to the next visit where I plan to try the gyoza which seem to be a pretty popular appetizer.
No comment
No comment

Amazing little treasure find with one of the best udon noodles ever! Small and quaint with a minimalistic feel to it, and great for small and intimate gatherings. Definitely worth the wait, staff is always soo nice and helpful.

Great food, great vibe, great spot! A small dinner place to meet up with one to two friends! The noodles are amazing and I love the frozen grapes they give with the check! Definitely check it out, it is now one of my favorite spots in the city to eat at!
No comment

The UDON noodles were amazing. I got the red crab udon with seaweed. The service was fast. The broth was light and clean tasting. The poached egg was cooked perfectly. If you want great Udon come here. Prices are very reasonable.
No comment

Saw the amazing reviews, so I decided to give this place a try. Maybe it was just the bowl I got or the day I went, but I was less than impressed. Certainly a huge portion of udon (I split it with one other person), but it wasn't outstanding in any way. Hits the spot if you're looking for udon in the East Village, though.
No comment

Stopped by on a Tuesday afternoon and it was relatively empty. Simple and clean exterior and interior. The space is small but more spacious than I expected. Polite and courteous staff. I ordered the ankake udon at around $10 and it was quite unlike other udon bowls I've tried. The bowl contained noodles, spinach, scallions, egg and ginger, apart from the broth. The broth was clear but really thick - gel-like. The noodles were chewy. I found the ginger taste a little bit too strong for my liking. Personally, I wasn't too crazy over this dish. Would recommend to those who seek unique twists on udon and/or appreciate a good dining environment.

This place is quite excellent. Well most other places have an option of about 3 to 5 Udon choices, this place had at least a dozen. My husband ordered gyunan udon and I ordered an unatama donburi. My dish had so much flavor and came wih some yummy soup and pickles on the side. We also got a bottle of cold sake which was such a great addition to the warm evening. This place is incredibly small so be prepared to wait it out!
The surrounding and the whole space is so chill and comforting. I like how Japanese restaurants usually keep their details perfect. Definitely going next time.

The niku udon is amazing, the broth is a bit on the sweeter side but I enjoyed it. The store is quite small so get there before it gets packed! The udon noodles are super soft and chewy. I would definitely come back for the niku udon!
No comment
No comment

I love the udon here. Every time, I have a great experience. It's just a small little shop you can easily walk by and miss. On the other hand, every bowl of udon I've had here has had all the perfect flavors and didn't lack anything. It's a must if you like udon noodles.
Good food, but shitty attitude. Very tinny space, they should really consider how to treat costumer well.
No comment

Hands down one of the best Udon bowls I've had in recent memories. I had the Chikara udon with added poached egg and shrimp tempura, which were fantastic. The appetizer that we shared, the chiken Tatsuta-age was also superb. Expect a 15-30 minutes wait, but you can leave your number and come back when they text you.
No comment
Best udon ever! I got the one with mochi in it. Never had mochi in a savory dish. It was yum. Seriously, don't miss this restaurant. Everything was executed to perfection. Cash only.
Good fried chicken and fried tofu app. Â Udons are better than average. Â Had the egg based one with crab and beef one. Â All good
This place is a piece of Japan in NY. Amazing udon! The service is also impeccable. Highly recommend

I came to Raku on a Monday night when I was really craving Japanese noodles. This place is really amazing and authentic the soup base is very umami and the noodles were the perfect consistency. I got the nameko udon and all the mushrooms were so fresh and cooked perfectly. Even though I was full half way through, I kept eating because I knew it wouldn't taste the same if I took home a to-go box . So definitely my go to noodle shop in the east village

I've been to raku atleast six times and each time I go it never dissapoints. The quality of the udon noodles is amazing and I also love the agedashi tofu and the edamame. The only issue is that it gets packed very quickly and they don't take credit cards. Would 100% recommend to anyone who is looking for some warm udon noodles on a cold wintery New York day!
Delish food and great service!! We got lucky and didn't even have to wait in line for seating. Get the niku hot udon and jaja cold udon.

Best udon I've had in the city! It's an extremely small place but once you go inside you feel as though you've been transported into a real noodle shop in Japan. It has a real simple and Zen feel to it. Anyway, I ordered the Ebiten Udon (Shrimp Tempura) and when it came out I was pleasantly surprised to see that there were two lightly fried pieces of shrimp and a slice of eggplant tempura sitting on a plate above a deep bowl of steaming hot udon. Usually the shrimp is already in the broth and then it gets all soggy by the time it reaches your table, so I enjoyed the fact they separated them and the way it was presented overall. Anyway, the broth itself is really light yet deep in flavor and honestly the favorite part for me was the chewy noodles. The noodles were thick but look and tasted freshly made and hand cut. It was just the perfect texture and comes with a nice amount of spinach. I thought that it wouldn't be filling (I have a big appetite), but that bowl is deeper than you might imagine and there was a good hefty amount of noodles. You basically won't leave there stinkin' full, but you won't be hungry either. Anyway, I would definitely come back to try more! The Ebiten I ordered was $14, and most of the noodles will range from $12-$18. Oh, and it's CASH ONLY.
food is fantastic environment is fantastic but the services is just so so. If service if not a big deal to you then Raku is a good place for enjoying Â meal.

Everything here is amazing! The noodles are cooked to perfection with the perfect chewiness udon should have. The soup is clear and flavourful, it's hard to not drink it all. I've tried almost half the udon choices here and haven't been disappointed yet! This is a must try and a must come-back-to restaurant!

Warm hot soup with Japanese thick cut udon noodles. We got the dumplings for starters and was definitely not disappointed. This place is a well curated small intimate space, carefully designed with well crafted wooden small Â tables and wooden side table bar seating. I loved my egg drop soup with noodles. Food is absolutely delicious with warm service. Perfect for any chilly winter night in NYC!

The place was soooooooo tiny... Nonetheless, the foods were amazing. It was huge and delicious. The noodles tasted like home-made udon with the texture of ramen and udon. Soup was so tasty. RECOMMENDED!

The food here is outstanding. I had the ebiten udon and added the fried bean curd - so so good. Wish I would have seen the other reviews first and I would have tried the karage. I just came back from Tokyo a few weeks ago and this is as good or better than any udon I had there. You can reserve a place in line on Yelp and I recommend doing so. Also warning: cash only!
No comment

This is one of my favorite noodle places! It's very subtle and minimalistic, which I love and the food is always so good! If you come here, you definitely have to order udon, and there are several types to choose from, plus toppings if you want a little something extra. The noodles are fresh and chewy and always served piping hot (unless you order cold udon). The workers are polite and helpful and always fulfill a request quickly. The only downsides to this restaurant are that: 1) it's a cash only establishment, so if you want to eat here, be sure to bring $20-30 per person and 2) it's very small and they don't take reservations as far as I know so you're unlikely to be seated immediately if you have a medium to large sized group. Other than that, this restaurant is one you should definitely go to!

My favorite udon in the city by far. I introduce only the people I trust to this tiny sanctuary with handmade udon and some of the best broth I've ever tried. The niku udon is reminiscent of Taiwanese beef noodle soup and pho and so, so wonderful.
To go spot for udon. This place is really small, it can get really busy during dinner time. But overall, this place is good and its CASH ONLY.

This is my third time at Raku and i have to say it hasn't let me down at all. I had the katsu-don, the duck breast the short rib udon and man... the quality of the soup and the meat are phenomenal! The space inside is rather small, but the ambiance is also another great thing about this place. Definitely will be my go-to noodle spot for a good while
First time trying the handmade udon, that was really good. The soup wasn't strong and salty like others. But CASH ONLY really took some points off!!!
No comment
No comment

Amazing. Best soups in nyc! I love coming here. It's such a small and cute Restarant. Yes the wait is over thirty minutes usually every time I come. But I can't not go here. I love the environment and the food here. This place will always be my go to udon soup place.
This is the best niku udon I have ever had! The beef was delicious! And the fried chicken was also wonderful!!!!! The tofu looks good, but not my style...
Small family run udon shop. High quality broth and noodles. Great on a cool, rainy day.
No comment
Noodles were awesome, the atmosphere was cozy and the servers were friendly. This place is cash only though!

This place is like a hidden gem! Makes you feel like your in Japan. The food is good overall but some broths can be a bit salty. The service is good and the frozen grapes for dessert was awesome! Definitely will be revisiting.

Love this udon place! I always get the edamame (salted perfectly) & niku udon. The noodles are handpulled, soup and ingredients are fresh and authentic. **It's cash only and sometimes there is a wait (although it's totally worth the wait). Highly recommend!

I remember coming here around a year ago during the height of December when the East Coast was at its coldest. My brother and his girlfriend decided to take me here for a fun time. The Chikara Udon is incredibly delicious and the homemade udon really do make a difference. The texture is unbeatable and they absorb the soup perfectly. The mochi was also a perfect delight of chewiness and stretchiness; I would recognize anything else. Please go here!
No comment

Came here spontaneously with my family last night. Since it started getting cold, we were all craving something hot and soupy. This place is pretty small but that's just how it is in East Village. Luckily, there were available seats when we came in but a few minutes later - the place was packed. We each ordered different udon. My mom had the duck and my sister ordered the Niku (beef with tripe). I got the Gyunan udon that came with wagyu beef and negi. What really impressed me was the noodles themselves, it's not the typical factory made udon but actually looks like it's handmade! The broth is just right in terms of flavor; however I wish it was a little more dense as I personally like thicker broths. If you're ever up for some udon, I would definitely recommend giving this place a try!
This place has the best affordable udon I've had! The service was great and the store's aesthetic is cozy.

Absolutely love the food here but at the end of my meal, the waiter asked if we'd like ice cream so of course we said yes. When we got the check, we had been charged for the ice cream. Would be nice if the waiter could mention that it's an additional charge and not just something nice they include with the meal haha. It was a surprising add on.
First meal in East Village. A really small place but really amazing food!
I don't like soup but this is somehow the best soup I've ever had. Everything has a nice savory taste to it. The fried chicken is great too.

I prefer soba, but Raku was pretty spot on with the udon. Raku's udon looks and tastes different than most udon places and it didn't feel like it was very heavy filling. I had the nameko udon adding mochi - very large portion and delicious. We also ordered agedashi tofu, which I would say was one of the best I've had in a very long time. Raku is very small, we got here at 6:00 on a Thursday summer night and had no problem getting a table. I will assume it must get very busy later. Cash only!!

Came here the other day for dinner and got the niku udon (short rib and tripe). It was sooo delicious. The noodles don't taste too doughy and the broth is very good. Perfect soup for a chilly night. I'll def be coming back again!

Solid udon, but not as amazing as all these reviews are making it out to be. The burdock root appetizer was quite good but a bit sweet, and the broth for both our udons was a bit too salty. I might try it again for the Niku udon but the sansai udon was not amazing.
No comment
The best udon noodles! The texture of the noodles was fantastic. I can't really explain it. Each bowl that we had was a delicious broth with different accompaniments. Also the seaweed app was great
No comment

I'm originally from Tokyo but sadly a lot of Japanese food doesn't live up to my standards here in New York because it doesn't taste right or it's too expensive. Raku is not the case. It's reasonably priced and very delicious. I went here with some of my friends from Japan and we had a great time. I believe I had the Jaja-udon, which is a cool combo of two of my favourite noodle dishes! I tell everyone I know this is the best udon spot in New York. And don't forget to mention, the interior decor is so cute too! And love that it's very small and doesn't seat many--so OG Nihon style
No comment

Waited for 40min to get a seat for two, because this is a small place. We ordered shrimp udon, swordfish liver and fried chicken. I like the texture of udon, very chewy. Chicken is better to eat with lemon juice only, sauce is too rich

Possibly the best udon I've ever had, The noodles are thick and yummy and the broth is rich. Super cute place, entrance is lowkey, made me miss Japan. Appetizers are wonderful I recommend chicken karage and the small fried fish. Cash only but they have an ATM in a cabinet by the kitchen.
No comment
Excellent. Clean, very simplistic yet very deep flavors. Great udon. Amazing decor, it really does look like that on the outside. Great service, very attentive. Great dashi.
No comment

Great noodles, BUT the service is the rudest I have experienced in a long time. First waitress tries to snatch my soba from me while still in the middle of slurping up noodles from a half full bowl. Can you please not? Upon finally finishing dinner, literally one 1 minute after we payed the check, second waitress comes up and asks us to leave because there is "a line out side". I tell them they are being rude. Response: Thank you so much for understanding! I DON'T understand. Please Raku, look at this line: "If this is supposed to be a come and go fast-food joint, please advertise so and adjust your prices. And please kick out your rude personnel". Never going here again. Zero Stars
Never really liked udon until I've tried this place. Absolutely delicious with fresh noodles, sake and more
No comment
Holy crap is this place good! Just go there and eat it. No further words needed.
Liked it a lot! Had unagi don instead of udon. Will definitely come and try udon another time

First of all, the restaurant is super easy to miss as there is no large sign. In a way, that makes it very seemingly secretive and only those looking for it will find it. Everything inside is very neatly organized, albeit a bit cozy. The lighting is warm and it complements the wooden tables well. The bathroom is even pretty cool as it has a sliding door and is well kept. As per other yelp reviews, Â I tried the Niku Udon option and I definitely was not disappointed. Coming in a large black bowl, the soup fills it about 3/5 of the way. The broth has a very pleasant, savory smell that is very enticing. The udon noodles are chewy in a good way and not too soft at all. It absorbed the flavoring of the broth very well too although I would say the broth by itself is a tad too salty. The beef is still mildly red on inside and it tears easily apart with each bite. The beef tripe is very tender as well. Overall, it was a enjoyable environment and the food was quite excellent. It is a bit more expensive though but the experience is definitely worth it.
Udon here is made in house and absolutely delicious. Agadachi was one of the best I have had! Very small restaurant with intimate seating. Worth it!

Came here for an early Saturday lunch. A very cozy kind of atmosphere. Ordered a two tempura udon which came with a large bowl of udon, spinach, and scallions as well as two shrimp tempura and eggplant. 10/10. Will definitely be coming back again.
No comment

My go to spot for udon. I love the nameko udon but chikara and niku are also great- I find the broth for niku a bit sweet. The pressed mackerel side was also very good. I really want to try the cold udon but can't resist the hot ones

This small shop has a really authentic feel. The prices for the appetizers are super reasonable, would highly recommend the fried chicken and the deep fried tofu dishes. I'm a huge fan of udon so I was really excited to try their hot noodle dishes. They were very generous portions but nothing special. I had the curry beef udon so it might just be a bad pick (was expecting a curry consistency but instead it was very soupy), would be happy to come back and try other flavors to see if they are better!

If you're in nyc and have tried raku yet have you been to nyc?! Their hospitality and food and everything about the restaurant makes you want to go back! Plus the price is super reasonable! And did you know their udon is handmade!!!??
No comment

Small space with minimal distractions, Raku offers genuine cuisine with exceptional delicacy. Seats rotate quite efficiently to house as many craving customers as possible. Easily an East Village regular dinner spot for those in the know.
No comment

Yes, I liked the food. They had plenty of space and not a lot of people were eating anyways, but they wouldn't let me and my friend sit in the seating area but the balcony. They said because it's gonna get "busier", but by the time we left it didn't get any busier, but less people. So they should really learn how to give the best service for it is service in the end, not the taste of food that will bring back their customers. I ain't going back after how they treated us.

Their food doesn't look attractive on the photo and I was hesitate to go. But I'm glad that I trust yelp review and tried this place! Food was so yummy and udon was prefect! They probably hand made the udon, so it's very different and more delicious with the traditional udon you could buy from Asian supermarket. We also tried the fried chicken and fish liver. Both are very delicious and fresh made! I would go again and try out different meal on the menu. This place is cash only. Remember to bring enough cash! :)
Great udon spot. Not many seating so it could get packed quickly. The soup base is very tasty. Karaage was good too. We will be back for more!
No comment

This place is so cute and authentic! The entrance is a sublet wooden door with no sign that says "raku" so make sure to watch out for it. We went at 6:30 pm on a Tuesday and there was no long but by 8 pm there was a line. The service was great and fast and friendly. The shrimp tempura and eggplant udon was delicious! Tasty and flavorful soup with long chewy udon noddles. The shrimp and eggplant was perfectly fried. It was a great experience! Great atmosphere.
The best udon I've had (including a previous trip to Japan). Â I had the vegetable tempura udon and my partner had the curry udon. Both had amazing flavor and the texture of the noodles was perfect.
Ja Ja cold udon. Done. It has a hint of slickness but it's so well marinated and is so refreshing during the hot summer months.
This place is such a vibe! The food is delicious and the people are super friendly and welcoming!
Excellent sushi dinner with very attentive service and a sake lesson. Delicious tuna and sea urchin. Hope to return soon!

Excellent quality ingredients. Â Excellent cooking execution. Â However my gyunan (washugyu beef hot udon) didn't really have that much flavor. Â Make no mistake the quality of the beef, udon, spinach were excellent. Â Perhaps the taste is just as intended. Â It's just my taste preference. Â I'm not a expert on udon noodles per se but it seemed pretty good. Â  Service was polite if indifferent. Â Price for value is spot on. Â My friend told me to get the chicken tatsuta-age but I didn't want that much food as I was by myself.
incredible food! so good and amazing for covid friendly dining (heaters and outdoor seating and their soup is so good). very friendly staff and can't recommend enough !! note cash only though

the food was OK, tastes good quality and whatnot, but the waitress was super rude. i called asking if there would be a wait if i came there in 5 minutes and she said no. when i got there 5 min later, she said theres a 15 min wait. i asked her why she told me no wait before and she was like well that was 5 min ago this is now!! she glared at me the whole night and when i asked if my side of rice was coming (all of our dishes had been served except the rice) she straight up ignored me and i had to ask another waiter for the rice. one star for mean staff and mediocre food

Tastiest udon I've had in a while. This place is always packed with tons of people waiting out the door, and that's not just because the space is small. It's located in a cozy little room. We were lucky - we were able to beat the lunch crowd on a freezing cold weekend. The decor, the service, and the food transported me back to Japan. I ordered the short rib udon - the flavor of the meat and broth, and the freshness of the udon and other ingredients, were perfect. The portion size was also very generous for the price in my opinion. Just note this place is cash only, and they have an ATM inside.

This was an authentic Japanese udon place. My friend and I had this fried chicken appetizer, the curry chicken udon which was very flavorful and nice and the green tea! The wait time is long but well worth it!
This place has the best udon I've ever tried in the city. The pork gyoza is also amazing. Have to give the dipping sauce five stars!
No comment
No comment
No comment

So I come here looking for a big bowl of hot noodle soup. The curry sounds good. And usually you get the nice broth with a hint of curry spice. My soup comes out very thick, almost glue texture. I asked them if it should be like that and they said curry is thicker than other soups. This wasn't written on the menu and not explained by the waiter when I ordered. I tried to eat it but couldn't. I asked if I could replace it with something else. I was told that once the food comes out they don't take it back and that I would have to pay for the other order. This is ridiculous. Never had this experience at a restaurant. She said Japanese curry is always thicker but how the hell are customers supposed to know that. They should be more descriptive on the menu and more accommodating. Not a good experience at all.

Arguably the best Udon noodles in America... just the perfect texture and it travelled well for delivery! Had the curry udon - would recommend extra noodles if your hungry. The curry had a nice balance of onions and meat (dark).

The first time I got the Ankake udon and I absolutely loved it. The broth is slightly thick, but it's very comforting especially on a cold day. The second time I went, I got the curry udon. I liked the Ankake udon more than the Curry udon, but it was still delicious. The only reason that keeps me from coming back to this place is their wait time. Literally I had to wait hours to be seated.
No comment

Great place to go if you're looking for a good bowl of udon in NYC! I had the gyunan udon and loved it - the udon was soft and chewy, and the broth was clean and refreshing. We came on a Saturday evening around dinnertime and there was a 45 minute wait, so definitely come early if you can to beat the dinnertime crowd, especially since the restaurant is rather small with limited seating. It can get quite loud in the restaurant because of the small seating area, but the food makes up for it. This place can be easy to miss since there isn't a sign, but be on the lookout for a wooden door covered by white and blue curtains. Highly recommend this restaurant if you're in east village!
No comment

When I came here it wasn't very crowded. I ordered a nameko udon and shared a thick cut bacon appetizer. The bacon was pretty good but it's so flavorful and fatty that I don't think I could finish it myself. The nameko udon had Waianae seaweed and mushrooms in it. The broth was good and the noodles were really nice and chewy. The service was nice too.
No comment

I just love love love the udon here, the noodle is so soft and chewy at the same time. I'm not that impressed with the appetizers though. But remember to bring cash since it's cash only, and there's always a line at night on weekends.
I think this is the best Udon in town! Had Niku udon, ankimo, fried chicken today, love every dishes! The noodles itself is good enough!!

So overrated. The soup base was literally soy sauce, salt and water plus whatever the topping u got. The portion of the udon was big for a Japanese restaurant but the ankimo appetizer had only 1 piece where all other restaurants I've been to at least give 3 pieces for cheaper price. Â Will not come back and not recommend to any one I know.
Best udon in Manhattan(not as good as in Japan) and shouldn't miss the thick cut bacon too.
Very original taste of food materials. Noodle udon is very chewy. Broth is properly thick. Â Bill gift was two frozen red grape - sweet surprise!
No comment

It was a happy accident that we ended up finding this gem in a city ripe with excellent cuisine. There is only seating for about 20 people, at best, but this place is absolutely worth the wait. We sampled almost everything on he menu. Too difficult to choose a favorite. Just go. You will not be disappointed.
No comment
No comment

Fantastic authentic Japanese food here. We ate here twice and both times were delicious!! Small room with Japanese decor and great dinnerware saves you a trip to Japan!! I suggest the crab ramen , duck ramen and the wagu beef.
Great environment and very good noodles. Big bowl and hearty. This is a cash only establishment but there's an ATM.

A small udon place near 1st avenue. I especially like their decoration from the moment I saw their door. Most of the udons are vegetable based. Absolutely love the fried tofu and fried eggplant appetizer. For entree, we tried the beef tripe one and the rice cake udon. I think I'd prefer the beef one though it tasted a bit like the Cantonese style beef noodle. But my friend thought it's a bit strong in the "beefy" flavor. I don't like the rice cake one so much because it is a bit plain. But all in all it's a good hang out place!
Really yummy comfort food. Makes me feel warm and fuzzy. Udon is hand made. Line may be long but very worth it! They told us the line was an hour long but it ended up being around 40 minutes.
Raku udon noodle will be the udon noodle that I'll miss the best in NYC. The soup, the meat, the noodle-all of these elements are amazing
No comment

The Kamaage Udon was great even though it's simple. It comes in plain hot water with separate dipping sauce. The sauce is a bit sweet and extremely flavorful. The noodle itself is a bit thicker than usual and is extremely filling. Everything is reasonably priced and even though the restaurant is on the smaller side the service is quick.

Been to this place once and ordered on Postmates many times in the past year. I love noodle, soup and this place. The broth is amazing with nice protein toppings. The waitress that helped us were nice and welcoming. I also really liked the sparkling sake they had. Will be back!

Hands down my favorite place to get udon! We did have to wait a bit after putting our names down in this small restaurant - you also will lose your table if your entire party is not there within minutes of them calling your name. This place was perfect for a cold day in NY. I had the ankake udon - kind of like egg drop soup. The noodles were soo good and fresh, definitely the highlight of this place. I had a side of shrimp tempura which was light and not greasy. My friend had the niku udon (shortrib and honeycomb tripe) which was very tasty and flavorful. I was able to order this to-go so I could have it later. Cash only.

It's a great feeling when you walk out of a restaurant feeling good about yourself -- that it you're full but don't feel like you overate, that you're healthy? Raku's food felt healthy and light. The wait can be pretty long, but the staff was very friendly and accommodating.
No comment
Amazing place. A little hard to find but it is certainly worth it. Smaller place and cash only. The hand pulled udon is outstanding. I can't praise this place enough. Just go there and eat.

We went there Saturday night and waited about 30 minutes. I really loved the fried oysters, fried tofu and mackerel sushi. Oysters tasted very fresh. The udon bowl was so big as you can see in the picture comparing to my hand lol. Service was good. We also ordered eel and egg rice to go, it was still really good the next day! I would definitely recommend to my friends!! I also post the pictures on my ins: shangyiliuuu

I came right before the crowd and got seated right away and I ordered the beef ribs with beef tripes. The broth was so flavorful and tasty. The noodles are so chewy, and I think it tastes like hand made udon. It is as good as what I had in Japan! Although it's a little pricy, it's ok to have it once a while :)

I love their niku Udon and it is also the only one I've tried. It's delicious and definitely quite the bowl to warm you right up in the cold winter. I only go for this dish because it has the most amount of meat. Â It is on the pricier end.
It's a good noodle place don't get me wrong, they just don't kick people out who have already finished eating and make you wait forever.

Had the ja ja cold udon. It was amazing. Spicy pork with thin slices of cucumber. Noodle texture was great. Not too tough not too soft. Great flavors. Place was a bit hot indoors because it's summer time. Great for a quick bite.

I am shocked that the ramen market in the city still have space for new places like this. Yet I am very glad that they open up. Specializing in udon, the homemade noodle beats everybody else in the neighborhood. Definitely will go back.

This is the best beef udon I ever had in Manhattan! The restaurant is very initiated and cozy and yet very clean and neat. The beef stripe in the noodle give extra texture to the soup base. The soup has very rich beef flavor and the meat in the udon is soft, well cooked but not over cooked. On thing on spot is the udon noodle is hand pulled freshly made everyday. You could see it was clipped in the end. The udon is strong but not chewy, very soft to bite. Chicken karage is very crispy and tasty. Overall great experience!! Five star recommended for small group. It maybe a waiting time for an hour for any group lager than 4 people at regular dining time.

The food was delish!! Absolutely amazing. I had the opportunity to dine here when my family went on a vacation to New York. If I were to visit again, I would definitely dine here again. The cold udon was my favorite.
Really good vegetarian udon! I've eaten a lot of noodles, and Raku stands out to me as one of my favorites. Had to wait but it was worth it.
Very impressive udon. Perfect for a cold day. Attentive and detail-oriented staff. Will go back and try different dishes.

The udon here is delicious and the portion size of the noodles is pretty generous. But be aware that some of the extra topping orders can be pretty small. If you add shiitake mushroom to your order, you're actually adding 1 mushroom for $2. The seating is super limited and tightly packed too.
No comment
This is the best udon place in the city!!! Â I love this place so much that I want to move next to here and come here everyday. The appetizers are delicious! Â Udon selections are omg!!!!

Amazing restaurant that serves one of the best udon bowls in New York. Cute ambiance and great service! I would recommend the Niku Udon, Karaage, Agedashi Tofu, Sansai Udon, Nameko Udon and Oroshi Udon.

Would not come again. The place is so small and cramped and one of the servers is unreasonable especially for a customer who was being polite and waited outside of the shop to save them room when everyone else wasn't. Terrible hostess. The first lady was nice and accommodating though. The food is okay you can get Â the same elsewhere; nothing special.

OMG!!! This is one of the best udon noodles I have ever had!!! The texture was so chewy and perfect. The broth super delicious and tasty. I'm so glad I came here today with the weather gloomy and rainy outside. Its the perfect place to end my day. Thanks Raku!!! Please come here and try this place cause you won't regret it.
Great Udo and the weird ancient Japanese BMG... Btw, the hidden ATM blew my mind. LOL

If you like udon, definatly a good place for it. Unfortunately I'm not a big fan but I still found alot to like about the place. It's a small spot so expects waits for seating, but there is alot of variety on the menu and the appetizers are pretty tasty. Pricing is pretty reasonable as well + good service!

This is by far the best udon place I've been to outside of Japan. Not only that but, the service was amazing. The food is fresh and packed with flavor. Yes it is a small restaurant but don't let that fool you. Each bite is perfect no matter what you have. Therefore I suggest this to anyone seeking great food packed with flavor.
No comment
Delicious, homey, comfort food. The vibe of this place is so relaxing and the service makes me feel very welcomed. The udon noodle has such a great texture, best I have ever had!

The staff here are exceptionally nice and the food is really good! Go with the braised tuna for an appetizer and make room for their top notch udon noodles. They have a perfect consistency and the broth is surprisingly flavorful. Cold or hot I don't think you can go wrong with the udon quality at this place. Definitely want to come back.
Small place tucked away on a busy street. Very understated, if you're not paying attention you could totally miss it. Absolutely delicious!

Honestly, doesn't matter how good the food is, nobody should be waiting for a table for two hours because they don't know how to assign tables. It's super frustrating and deeply disheartening. I'm Â very easy going but this is so not okay

Omg i love this place! I came here ard 5:30pm so the wait time wasn't that bad. I ordered chicken appetizer and curry udon, it's the BEST udon I've ever had in my life!!! Will definitely come back again, I love it love it, and I'm craving their udon right now at 1am, yea, that's why im writing this review :D
Niku Udon tastes amazing, strongly recommend it. If the restaurant could cards it would be better.
Nice semi-discrete shop. Great service. I got the Raku udon, which had an amazing broth but just slightly too salty for my taste.
No comment

Sooooo yummy! I got the Niku Udon. Portions are big, I couldn't finish my bowl even though I wanted to. The place is super cute and tiny - we went in on a Tuesday night and we grabbed the last two seats by the wall without having to wait. Oh and it's cash only!

This is probably my fav noodle spot in the city. I originally wanted ramen nearby but ended up coming to try their udon. I was really impressed with the texture of the hand pulled udon noodles as well as the broth itself. I'm usually one to go for the fancier dishes but I went with a simpler udon (forgot the name but it was with mountain veggies and mushroom tempura) and it was amazing. Just everything about it was really good. Even from the vibe the outside and inside, to the attentive service and clean bathroom, everything exceeded my expectations of a nyc resto.
No comment
So far i love the beef udon soup. The bowl is impressive. It is huge. Wish they could put more udon in because I can eat more. Nothing negative so i give it 4 stars

This is the best udon place, hands down. Try any. The chicken karaage appetizer is worth a mention. If you want to avoid the 1+ hour wait, try coming right when they open or later around 9:30pm for a late dinner.
The food was great, and so was the service. The waitresses were very informative about the menu. This place can be a bit hard to find if you don't keep a close eye out for it.

This place simply has some of the best noodles in Manhattan. The broth is insanely good too. If you're not sure what to add to your soup, you can ask the servers and they'll give you some suggestions. I had the duck and a runny egg. It was fantastic. Top 5 bowl of soup in my entire life
No comment
Great place for food in a chilly weather. The portion is large. We were so full finishing everything. We loved the appetizers - deep fried chicken and tofu as well.
Really tasty Japanese food in a very clean minimal space. Â Delicious soups and great for winter. Â Lines can be long.
Every time I come here it's amazing. Love their Honeycomb tripe and short rib Noodles!!!
Bawitdabadabangadamgdiggydiggydiggysaid the boogie said up jump the whoogie. I was surprised by the adequate proportions and the soup was just right ordered the short rib soup. Happy wid my choice
No comment
I got the Niku Udon and wow the broth (flavorful and not too salty), the noodles, the tripe and ribs were all on point! My new favorite udon place in NYC...!!!

Deliciously chewy, with the right amount of bounce and snap. Yes, I'm describing the udon noodles of my dreams that come along the most delicious udon broth I've ever had. Broth had depth and pieces of honeycomb tripe and short ribs and was so good that I took the leftover broth home and ate it with some rice the next day. Don't judge. We also started with ankimo which is always delicious. The place is pretty small and there was a slight wait.

I really love Japanese food and i can say - this place is awesome. The Udon noodles so delicious! I mean it's totally different from other places. Soups are also amazing, friendly and price is good. Highly recommend it.

Best udon in NYC in my opinion. I tried the wagyu beef udon, the chicken with mochi udon, the beef tribe udon and they were all really good. The noodle Â is definitely the star of the meal, it's so chewy and tasty even without the broth.
No comment

I was happy with the beef stew undo I have. The soup is delicious, the noodle is very chewy. Great atmosphere. Had fun with friends there. Would love to visit again and try all the eel and egg on rice.
BEST handmade udon ever! (PS. it's cash only)
No comment

The place is nice but it's a bit dark and rlly small and tight space. When I first went in one of the waiters was a bit rude then after I got 2 diff ones and they were a lot nicer. The food there is good but over priced. I would recommend but I wouldn't go back too often cause it's so pricey.
The udon is amazing. They use thicker udon with soup and thinner udon for dipping. Delicious fried chicken. Cash ONLY but they have an ATM on site. Very clean restroom.

Was not impress. Had the mild curry chicken and there were only three tiny pieces of chicken in that large bowl of broth. Also had vegetable dumplings and there was barely any vegetables in it. They were stuffed with some creamy stuff and tasteless.
Horrible service! Servers will rush you to order and take plates off the table before you even finish eating. Will not return, absolutely disgusting mannerism!

Cute Japanese place. The pricing is reasonable and the interior is minimalistic in an interesting way. Not too much space tho! It could be a nice cozy Sunday night place to have Japanese soups. The portions are quite bigger than normal... Our soups were thick and spicy.
No comment
Hands down the best udon place in the city and my must go to place on a rainy day Everything on the menu is worth ordering
One of the hidden jewels in East Village. It's comfortable, and a quiet respite from the tireless city. Their udons are reasonably priced and some of the tastiest in the city. Highly recommended!
I don't usually like udon and the udon here blows me away. It's silky smooth and not too hard and not too soft. The niku don is HUGE and has tripe and tender pieces of beef. Worth the $16.

Udon lovers rejoice! This place is like udon west but way nicer and cuter for around the same price. The servings here are huuuuge. You could wear the bowls they use as a big hat. The ankake udon is kind of like udon in thick egg drop soup. It's yummy and filling. The curry udon is also a good option. The curry is flavorful and not too spicy. Come here for one bowl of noodles and it can last you thru brunch and dinnertime. And the bowls of noodles and the interior and the little ombre drape entrance is all insta-worthy.
No comment
It's small place but they decorate as minimalism. Beautiful decor, friendly staff, great Udon menu (large servings).
No comment

Quite good. The noodles are imported from Japan and have a great mouth feel. The broth is tasty. I ate everything in my bowl. The service was friendly and really accommodating when I wanted to take photos of my food. Yeah, I should probably share them on this review.
I love the curry udon and thick cut bacon here. The wait could be long though. I always try to go after 130pm for lunch so we don't have to wait for too long.
No comment

Our go-to spot for udon - Â the noodles are springy and chewy but not heavy and the selection of different broths and toppings is great. Curry udon one of my favorites, though we've had a few different ones across visits and they've all been delicious. The braised tuna appetizer is also delicious.

No one greeted us at the door. We stood there for a good amount of time, they were just chatting amongst themselves until we approached them. Customer service was "nice" but we felt super rushed within 2 minutes of sitting down, didn't even get to see the menu and we were asked 3x "are we ready"? When the bill came the money barely touched the table, the waiter tried to grab it I did not even get the chance to recount the money. Food was good. First and last time there, will not be going back due to the service.

This place was great. Â Was very impressed by the quality of the Udon. Â I deserves the tremendously good reviews posted. Â Quick note - the area inside is not very large. Â So if your party members are not already there when you arrive, it would probably make sense to wait outside. Â Though I would say that this restaurant is well worth the wait.

I ordered the Niku Udon which has beef short ribs & honeycomb tripe but was sad to see my bowl had no tripe at all :( There was a TON of beef though. My friend had ordered the same thing so I tried a piece of her tripe and it was sooo good.
Best udon I've ever had. After looking at its reviews, I decided to try it myself. So nice the udon noodles are. I would put it No.1 udon restaurants in NYC.

This place was amazing. The food is absolutely delicious. You can tell that the noodles are homemade and they have the perfect amount of elasticity and chew to them. The broth was also great. I can't wait to go back and try all the different types of udon noodles they have. They also have donburi but I didn't see anyone eating that (the place was packed) probably because the udon was so delectable
Wait to get in was a little long, but totally worth it. Great ambiance and the food was delicious.
I feel like they've managed to differentiate themselves with more authentic Japanese ramen. This will satisfy food snobs

The consistency of the noodles are absolutely perfect. It is the right amount of chewy and for some reason stays that way no matter how long you leave them in the broth (they don't get soft or start disintegrating). Highly recommend the agedashi tofu and niku udon
ordered mushroom and veggie udon, soup was flavorful, this place is rather small but simple and decent inside.

Came here on my birthday as a second option based on the glowing 5 star reviews everybody here gave on Yelp. Â Super overrated to the point i can say i can make udon better than this at home. Â Nothing to work home about. Â I wanted to ask for my money back.

While the udon noodle bowl were pretty decent (the broth was pretty rich -- my girlfriend and I ordered the shrimp tempura udon bowl), menu itself was sparse (consisting mostly of udon) and Â the appetizer we ordered wasn't very appetizing at all (it was braised tuna which tasted like flavorless overcooked tuna and cost us $8 for a small portion of fish). Furthermore, our plans went a bit awry as they ONLY ACCEPT CASH and don't accept other forms of payment. I would recommend other restaurants for new visitors in NYC.
I really enjoyed this noodle-centric Japanese restaurant. Â I did feel that it could have been more flavorful, but it wasn't overly expensive and it was just what I was looking for. Â Recommended.

This little restaurant in East Village is really a gem. The udon noodles are amazing! There are a variety of broths, both light and heavy and the noodles are very fresh and has a similar bouncy texture as mochi. Highly recommend! Look out for their sister restaurant to open on the west side.
Best udon noodles ever. The yam & seaweed appetizer was amazing in a hot summer! Â  Def. will bring friends and families there. Seats always limited though.

If you're the kind of person who goes to restaurants for the experience than you will probably be fine here, since it's an interesting intimate space and everyone is very nice. It reminds me of tiny mom and pop shops I've been to in Japan, but they tried to upscale it and attract a young crowd. They succeeded with the young crowd, which is why I think the reviews are so good. BEWARE, the food is bad and overpriced. My curry udon tasted like curry powder jello. There was no heartiness in it that you would expect from authentic Japanese cooking. Other dishes were similar. Go there to check out the hype, but set your expectations low to have a good time and be ready for the pricey bill.
No comment

Fantastic udon. The noodles hand-made and flown from Japan and you can really taste the difference from the usual store-bought kind. They are chewy and flavorful and soak up all the tasty broth. Ingredients are impeccable, the space is minimalist and comfortable. Perfect for lunch (but gets very full)

Be patient you can't reserve and there are only 20 seats but it is worth the wait, very lovely service waitresses, excellent price quality ratio. It was very good. I had the katsu don. The decoration is very minimal, so the space, but for the ones we want to be transported back to a Tokyo restaurant atmosphere, this is it. Can only recommended it.

Go for the udon. It's smooth and chewy. I don't doubt they make it themselves. I got the short rib udon and it was more than enough to fill me up (compared to when I got the large udon from Tsutonron). The short rib was cooked perfectly. However, I didn't enjoy the soup as much and it could be hotter. Will come back to try another udon next time!
No comment

Yummy homemade Japanese udon chewy and filling. Soup is always delightful with enough favors not salty and greesy. Fried chicken and dumpling are good appetizers. Be aware of party of more 3 might be long wait since limited big tables inside.

I haven't been in NY for a few years and so I revisited Raku. Â I heard they opened the new location in China Town, and I felt the quality changed a little. Â Agedashi Tofu was very firm, and Kara age was very brown. It must be very hard to keep the quality since the waiting time is 20 min to 45 min. Â I missed the original tastes Raku used to have. Â If they started to serve ordinary stuff, it won't worth waiting in line.
Hole in the wall place with friendly service and a variety of udon choices. Definitely recommend getting a spicier broth. Portions are large and very filling- worth the price!

I came here for lunch one day. Not too busy during lunch since I went closer to opening, and they sat me at a two-person table instead of having to sit at the bar stools and face the wall (yay). The waitress came out with hot tea and water for me, and I ordered the curry udon. I must admit, I'm not an udon expert, and particularly, I wished there were more people inside so I could copy how to use that humongous wooden spoon paddle to eat my udon. Haha. The curry udon was good. It came out in this huge heaping big bowl. The broth itself was interesting.. I can't quite pinpoint it. It almost tasted watered down, but still had a runny thickness to it? Not sure how to describe. It was good though.

Great spot for udon! Really yummy broth and noodles have a well rounded texture. I like them a little more firm though. The appetizer portions are pretty small if you're trying to share. But overall one of my faves in this area. Small space. If you use the wait list feature on Yelp it's not too accurate. I waited 45 minutes on the list and when I got there, was told it would be another 20 minutes. That dampened the whole experience. But food was a 5 so I'd come back again at a less busy time.

SO amazingly good! Straight out of Japan, authentic udon. I just ordered the plain Kitsune udon and even that just blew me away - I highly recommend if you don't want something too heavy. But I did try my sister's curry udon and that was amazing as well! Just a lot if you're not super hungry. And lastly, the fried chicken is TO DIE FOR! That is a must. Okini!
My favorite place for udon and fried chicken. There might be several minutes of waiting for dinner, but Definitely worth waiting. The Unagi Don is also amazing.
No comment
No comment

Raku was delicious however it did not blow me away. The menu was simple and I tried the popular items, fried chicken and Niku udon. The fried chicken was the star of the meal, it was succulent and paired well with a spicy masago aioli. The noodles were unlike any other udon noodles I've ever had. I loved the texture/shape it was quite different not quite uniformly round. The niku broth was good however it just reminded me of a lighter version of Taiwanese beef noodle soup. Wish there was more options.

I was feeling sick and decided to stop by for a hot bowl of udon to feel better. i got the niku udon. the tripe was very similar to the tripe you can get at dim sum places (like with the turnip and whatnot, in the clear glass bowls). the broth was a bit salty but overall it hit the spot. it's a tad pricey (like $17-18 average for a bowl of udon) but it's a very hearty portion and you get a decent amount of tripe & meat.

This place was awesome! Actually I was looking for Ramen place via yelp, and it shows me 'wrong' result. So, I was kinda upset because they only have Udon. But, all foods were great and We will definitely go there again!!
No comment
No comment

Discreet exterior but definitely a lucky find. I've been searching for ramen in the city with the authentic umami flavor and this is by far the most exceptional! It's a small place but the wait won't be long and the service is fast. Definitely worth a try! I'll be back again!

Husband and I both got really sick after eating here. :( I don't know how or why but shortly after eating here we both felt a prickly feeling in our throats. Within a day I had a full blown worst flu of my life. Persistent 103 degree fever that keeps coming back, sore throat from hell, nausea for days, constant headache, chills, body ache... It's been a week and I'm still not better. I don't know what I got infected with but I'm never coming back here, that's for sure.

I love the texture of the noodles and how you can tell it's homemade. One bowl is super filling. My favorite is the Niku udon! The thick cut bacon appetizer wasn't bad, but I probably wouldn't get it again. It's not expensive at all considering it's in Manhattan and it's such a filling/authentic meal. The restaurant size is small, but I like that it's not too loud.
No comment
It's a cute small place selling different kind of udon noodles. Yummy but beware of a line.
Excellent small intimate dining experience! Â Attention to detail not only in the food but also the surroundings. Â Gyoza and udons were fantastic!
Tiny little cute shop. The signature beef noodle soup is amazing! Really loved the texture of the noodle and the fact that it doesn't get mushy in the soup is just wonderful!!!!!
No comment
Simple classic udon noodles in fresh broth, genuine Â Japanese atmosphere, quick and quality service
No comment

I've had a lot of udon, but this is the best udon i've ever had in my life. I had the Yasai Kakiage Udon. The noodles are made in-house, and they are the perfect amount of chewiness. The broth is clean and well seasoned.The vegetable tempura was perfectly crisp and piping hot. Cash only. Must try.

I never knew udon can be this good. This is opened by the owner of my all time fav sushi restaurant kura. Looking at the pictures I wasn't tempted to go, then ine day I ordered delivery. And now I'm addicted.
